Three other people were injured in the brawl, and Mack McClendon Teal, a man with a history of gang and nightclub connections, was charged with Cherry's murder. This event further highlights the club's involvement in illegal activities and the legal consequences faced by its members.

The Hells Angels' South Carolina Nomads chapter engaged in trafficking over a hundred firearms, including automatic weapons and sawed-off shotguns, as well as dealing drugs like methamphetamine, cocaine, bath salts, and prescription painkillers. The leadership of the Hells Angels' South Carolina Nomads chapter changed from veteran member "Diamond" Dan Bifield to newly initiated Mark "Lightning" Baker after Bifield was removed as president in a vote. The shift occurred as part of a law enforcement operation that began in 2011 when Bifield conducted a drug transaction with an informant. The operation resulted in the arrest of twenty individuals, including sixteen men and four women, in a series of raids in June 2012. The last of the arrested were sentenced in June 2013, with the group receiving over a century of combined imprisonment in Virginia.

In 2018, a confrontation between four Hells Angels members from the New York metropolitan area and two Pagans members from southern Virginia occurred at a motel in Greenville, resulting in one Pagan being shot and the other assaulted with a hammer. The Hells Angels members were later convicted for this ambush. This incident is part of the ongoing tensions between the two gangs.

In 2019, five Hells Angels members faced trials in Staunton and received sentences for their involvement in the 2018 attack on two Pagans members in Greenville. Dominick J. Eadicicco and Anthony Milan were convicted of malicious wounding by a mob and use of a firearm, receiving eight-year prison terms. Nathaniel A. Villaman, Joseph Anthony Paturzo, and Richard E. West were found guilty of malicious wounding by a mob and sentenced to four years each. These trials and sentences reflect the ongoing conflict between the two gangs.

The Hells Angels established a Nomads chapter in Washington state in 1994. In 2001, a former Hells Angel, Rodney Lee Rollness, and another member, Joshua Binder, murdered Michael "Santa" Walsh, who they believed had falsely claimed membership in the gang. Paul Foster, an aspiring member, assisted in the murder and helped conceal it. This information highlights the violent actions and internal conflicts within the Hells Angels gang.

The leader of the Hells Angels' West Coast branch, Richard "Smilin' Rick" Fabel, was found guilty alongside Rollness and Binder for committing racketeering crimes, further illustrating the gang's involvement in serious criminal activities and internal power struggles.
